awd_titl_txt: Probing the mechanical properties of the crust and upper mantle using geodetic, remote sensing and seismological observations
awd_abstract_narration:
The Accomplishments Based Renewal will shed light on the laws that govern continental deformation and the seismic cycle, such as the processes of strain release during large earthquakes and the slow strain build up between successive earthquakes. This topic is of broad interest in geology and the result of the research could significantly advance methods for seismic hazard assessment. These are questions that the recent National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine report Earth in Time note as grand challenge questions in the Earth sciences. The researchers will analyze and model high precision GPS measurements of ground deformation before, during and after large earthquakes in California and Tibet using novel methods developed by the lead researcher. The project will support educational and outreach activities by the PI to train students and postdoctoral researcher involved in the project. The project will foster international scientific collaboration.

The objective of this project is to advance the knowledge of crustal and upper mantle rheology and to improve the quantitative understanding of how seismicity relates to geodetic strain. The researchers will analyze High-Rate GNSS measurements of postseismic deformation and aseismic transients using a new methodology based on an Independent Component Analysis technique. They will compare the geodetic and seismicity observations with model predictions to constrain the friction properties governing the earthquake nucleation process and aseismic slip, and the viscosity structure. They will analyze data from California, related to the 2019, Mw7.1 Ridgecrest earthquake and the 2020 Westmorland swarm in particular, and data related to the Mw 7.4, 2021a Madoi earthquake in Tibet.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Our goal was first to quantify the impact of earthquakes and postseismic processes on Earth's surface deformation and next to draw implications regarding fault friction and the visco-elastic properties of rocks in the crust and mantle.

We used an advanced signal processing technique known as an Independent Component Analysis (ICA) to analyze data from a satellite system called GNSS (Global Navigation Satellite System), combining it with a remote sensing technique called InSAR (Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar), which uses radar waves to measure the displacement of the ground over time.

We studied the Westmorland earthquake swarm that occurred in Southern California in 2020. The study revealed that the earthquakes were triggered by a transient geodetic deformation signal that started about 12 hours before the onset of seismicity. This signal helped us understand how seismic activity is related to geodetic strain and validate a theoretical model of earthquake nucleation governed by rate-and-state friction. The findings were published in a paper by a PhD student in the lead researcher's group (Sirorattanakul et al., 2022).

In a follow-up study, we conducted a study to analyze how seismic activity in California responds to changes in surface load and strain related to groundwater storage changes. The study showed that the observed response can be accurately modeled, assuming a nucleation process governed by rate-and-state friction. This approach offers a unique way to examine fault friction and the stress state on a large scale. The study will be presented at the annual meeting of the Seismological Society of America (May 2024), and an article is in preparation (Sirorattanakul and Avouac, in prep).

We discovered a postseismic deformation signal following the M8.2 Fidji earthquake, which occurred at the bottom of the upper mantle (approx 560km) using the ICA technique. This signal revealed an unexpectedly significant signal than anticipated and had a short relation time of just one year. Our findings suggest the presence of a low-viscosity layer, approximately 100 km thick, at the bottom of the mantle transition zone. This weak layer could explain why subduction zones have flat slabs and orphaned plates, which are difficult to explain using conventional models. The low-viscosity layer may result from superplasticity induced by the postspinel transition, weak CaSiO3 perovskite, high water content, or dehydration melting. The results are presented in a study led by Sunny Park, who started the work when she was a postdoctoral fellow at Caltech (Park et al., Nature, 2023).

The third significant activity focused on determining the rheological layering of Tibet after the Maduo earthquake. This is part of a PhD study by Ojashvi Rautela. The activity in this work is well advanced but has proven more challenging than expected due to high noise levels in the InSAR time series. However, we have made progress by improving the atmospheric corrections. Currently, we are finalizing the modeling and preparing a manuscript.

 

Broader Impact 

The project has taken important steps towards creating an inclusive environment for learning and research by supporting the training of PhD students and postdoctoral researchers from diverse backgrounds and genders. This initiative has helped foster a more diverse and inclusive academic community, provided valuable skills and knowledge to researchers from all walks of life, and promoted a more equitable and scientific environment that benefits everyone involved. 

Our work has demonstrated the potential and paved the way for the application of Variational Bayesian Independent Component Analysis in tectonic geodesy. These great efforts have sparked a wave of exploration in our group and others. We are now exploring the potential of the vb-ICA technique for applications beyond tectonic geodesy, such as attempting to extract deformation signals caused by groundwater dynamics or reservoir operations.

 

References

Park, Sunyoung and Avouac, Jean-Philippe and Zhan, Zhongwen and Gualandi, Adriano. (2023). Weak upper-mantle base revealed by postseismic deformation of a deep earthquake. Nature. 615 (7952).

Sirorattanakul, Krittanon and Ross, Zachary E. and Khoshmanesh, Mostafa and Cochran, Elizabeth S. and Acosta, Mateo and Avouac, Jean‐Philippe. (2022). The 2020 Westmorland, California Earthquake Swarm as Aftershocks of a Slow Slip Event Sustained by Fluid Flow. Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth. 127 (11)

Sirorattanakul, Krittanon and Avouac, Jean‐Philippe. Earthquake nucleation process revealed by modulation of seismicity rate in California driven by tectonic, hydrological and tidal loading (in prep for Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth).


Last Modified: 04/26/2024
Modified by: Jean-Philippe Avouac
